prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Tuning 1/18
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal represents spectral setup 1 of 18 in the unbiased spectral survey of IRAS16293-2422.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to cover the 329.15 to 362.90 GHz range in Band 7 using the C34-3 configuration. Each ALMA-OT science goal in this program has been designed to observe one part of this frequency band at 0.5 arcsecond resolution. To increase the legacy value of the dataset we propose to obtain complementary ACA observations, which will be important especially for cold, extended emission of simple molecules. If for programmatic reasons the ACA data cannot be obtained, we can still carry out the bulk of our science objectives (as demonstrated with our earlier ALMA papers). We will not utilize the spectral scan mode because tests with the ALMA-OT show that the difference in execution times are minimal for our requested sensitivity and the spectral scan mode is not supported by the ACA. Each science goal will observe 4 basebands of 468.75 MHz in sequence to cover a bandwidth of 1875 MHz at 0.25 km/s spectral resolution (employing a factor 2 spectral averaging to limit the data rate). To cover the proposed frequency range we will therefore require 18 separate tunings. We aim for a sensitivity of 5 mJy/beam / (km/s). The deepest systematic survey so-far by Caux et al. using the JCMT to survey this frequency window reached a sensitivity of about 125 mJy/beam / (km/s). With the proposed observations we will thus be more than a factor 20 more sensitive - and furthermore produce high quality images at 0.5 arcsecond resolution separating the emission from the different regions in the IRAS16293 environment not resolveable by single-dish observations. This sensitivity level will be comparable to what was achieved in the band 6 SV data - and reach the confusion limit at selected frequencies.
The analysis will consist of (i) identification of the lines (by frequency and similar spatial distribution); (ii) simulating the observed emission of a molecule in LTE including optical depth of the lines, with the excitation temperature and number of molecules as free parameters; if required by the data, the fit can contain more than one temperature component; (iii) determining families of molecules that correlate spatially and calculating their abundance ratios for comparison with models; (iv) determining the spatial variation of excitation temperature and abundances by carrying out item (ii) in different apertures and at different radii. We stress that most of our science involves relative abundance ratios, in particular with respect to CH$_3$OH, which can be determined with much higher accuracy than absolute abundance ratios. With the proposed sensitivity, we can reach relative abundances with respect to methanol of 0.01-0.1\% and absolute abundances down to 1e(-11)-1e(-10) with respect to H2, depending on species. For molecules for which collisional rate coefficients are available, we can also carry out full non-LTE calculations for a given physical structure of the source, and this will be done for simple molecules like HCO+, HCN and their isotopologues to determine accurate isotope ratios.

We will not utilize the spectral scan mode because tests with the ALMA-OT show that the difference in execution times are minimal for our requested sensitivity and the spectral scan mode is not supported by the ACA. Each science goal will observe 4 basebands of 468.75 MHz in sequence to cover a bandwidth of 1875 MHz at 0.25 km/s spectral resolution (employing a factor 2 spectral averaging to limit the data rate). To cover the proposed frequency range we will therefore require 18 separate tunings. We aim for a sensitivity of 5 mJy/beam / (km/s). The deepest systematic survey so-far by Caux et al. using the JCMT to survey this frequency window reached a sensitivity of about 125 mJy/beam / (km/s). With the proposed observations we will thus be more than a factor 20 more sensitive - and furthermore produce high quality images at 0.5 arcsecond resolution separating the emission from the different regions in the IRAS16293 environment not resolveable by single-dish observations. This sensitivity level will be comparable to what was achieved in the band 6 SV data - and reach the confusion limit at selected frequencies.
The analysis will consist of (i) identification of the lines (by frequency and similar spatial distribution); (ii) simulating the observed emission of a molecule in LTE including optical depth of the lines, with the excitation temperature and number of molecules as free parameters; if required by the data, the fit can contain more than one temperature component; (iii) determining families of molecules that correlate spatially and calculating their abundance ratios for comparison with models; (iv) determining the spatial variation of excitation temperature and abundances by carrying out item (ii) in different apertures and at different radii. We stress that most of our science involves relative abundance ratios, in particular with respect to CH$_3$OH, which can be determined with much higher accuracy than absolute abundance ratios. With the proposed sensitivity, we can reach relative abundances with respect to methanol of 0.01-0.1\% and absolute abundances down to 1e(-11)-1e(-10) with respect to H2, depending on species. For molecules for which collisional rate coefficients are available, we can also carry out full non-LTE calculations for a given physical structure of the source, and this will be done for simple molecules like HCO+, HCN and their isotopologues to determine accurate isotope ratios.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Understanding how, when and where complex organic and potentially prebiotic molecules are formed is a fundamental goal of astrochemistry and an integral part of origins of life studies. Already now ALMA is showing its capabilities for studies of the chemistry of solar-type stars with its high sensitivity for faint lines, high spectral resolution which limits line confusion, and high angular resolution making it possible to study young stars on solar-system scales. We here propose to undertake an unbiased survey of the protostellar binary IRAS 16293-2422 in the important spectral window from 329 to 363 GHz. The aim is to reveal the origin of complex organic molecules in a young protostellar system and investigate the link between this stage and the early Solar System. These data will however also have a large legacy value beyond the astrochemical focus of our group and we will therefore waive the proprietary period for the obtained data - and furthermore make the fully imaged datacubes available to the community with the first sets of papers.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals:
A related proposal in Cycle 1 (2012.1.00712.S; PI Jes Jorgensen) was approved in Cycle 1 with the main aim of confirming our detection of glycolaldehyde from the SV observations (Jorgensen, 2012, ApJL, 757, L4) through observations in band 3.
Our Cycle 0 program targeting the kinematics and chemistry of two embedded protostars (2011.0.00628.S; PI Jes Jorgensen) has been succesfully executed and so-far resulted in two publications: Jorgensen et al. 2013, ApJL, 779, L22 (including an international press-release) and Lindberg et al. 2013, A&A, submitted.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
Niels Bohr Institute, Copenhagen, University of
Astronomy Department, Michigan at Ann Arbor, University of
Center for Radiophysics and Space Research, Cornell University
Institute of Physics I, Cologne, University of
Harvard College Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
